articles.headline: Even as Museum Piece, Confederate Flag Is in Dispute
articles.snippet: The divisions over how and where it is displayed are reflected in a Civil War museum in Richmond, Va., the former capital of the Confederacy.
articles.abstract: The divisions over how and where it is displayed are reflected in a Civil War museum in Richmond, Va., the former capital of the Confederacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — One floor below street level in the Museum of the Confederacy here, at the end of a cinder-block hallway behind two sets of locked double doors, a climate-controlled vault contains the world’s largest collection of some of the most revered and reviled objects in American history: Confederate-era flags.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Team Is Wary as Bernie Sanders Finds Footing in Iowa
articles.snippet: Challenging Bernie Sanders directly could elevate his candidacy, but the current path requires Hillary Clinton to put faith in caucusgoers who once jilted her.
articles.abstract: Challenging Bernie Sanders directly could elevate his candidacy, but the current path requires Hillary Clinton to put faith in caucusgoers who once jilted her.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ample crowds and unexpectedly strong showing garnered by Senator Bernie Sanders are setting off worry among advisers and allies of Hillary Rodham Clinton, who believe the Vermont senator could overtake her in Iowa polls by the fall and even defeat her in the nation’s first nominating contest there.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Angela Merkel Faces Monumental Test of Leadership After Greek Vote
articles.snippet: The German chancellor must find a way to maintain European unity and the euro as a currency while also devising an acceptable resolution to Greece’s financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The German chancellor must find a way to maintain European unity and the euro as a currency while also devising an acceptable resolution to Greece’s financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As chancellor of Germany, Angela Merkel leads a nation that prizes fiscal rectitude and adherence to the rules, and, after pledging tens of billions in bailout programs for five years, has expressed scant sympathy for Greece’s demand for more financial help.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: Chinese Investors Who Borrowed Are Hit Hard by Market Turn
articles.snippet: Most stock purchases in China are made by small players who don’t necessarily have the resources to withstand volatility or a lengthy downturn.
articles.abstract: Most stock purchases in China are made by small players who don’t necessarily have the resources to withstand volatility or a lengthy downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — With his stock market riches, Gong Yifeng bought a riverfront apartment here for his son and daughter-in-law. He can eat well and travel abroad. He can also afford to pay for his granddaughter’s education.

articles.headline: For Start-Ups, How Many Angels Is Too Many?
articles.snippet: The Silicon Valley investment frenzy has spurred so-called angel investors into earlier financing rounds, but there are downsides for both entrepreneur and investor.
articles.abstract: The Silicon Valley investment frenzy has spurred so-called angel investors into earlier financing rounds, but there are downsides for both entrepreneur and investor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after presenting her start-up to potential investors at a conference, Nancy Hua was bombarded by eager suitors. A little more than 48 hours later, the Silicon Valley entrepreneur had amassed about $2 million from wealthy individuals known as angel investors.

articles.headline: Pacific Trade Deal Negotiators See a Wrap in Late July
articles.snippet: U.S. officials feel confident enough of a deal that they have notified Congress that they expect the meeting among negotiators in late July will be the last.
articles.abstract: U.S. officials feel confident enough of a deal that they have notified Congress that they expect the meeting among negotiators in late July will be the last.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a final accord in sight, the 12 nations negotiating a trans-Pacific trade agreement linking 40 percent of the global economy have set a last round of talks for late July on the remaining issues on the most ambitious trade deal in a generation.

articles.headline: Iraqi Forces Plan Offensive to Retake Ramadi From ISIS
articles.snippet: President Obama said the fall of the key western city had galvanized the Iraqi government and accelerated an American effort to train forces there.
articles.abstract: President Obama said the fall of the key western city had galvanized the Iraqi government and accelerated an American effort to train forces there.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seven weeks after their frenetic retreat from Ramadi, Iraqi security forces are preparing to mount a counteroffensive in the coming weeks to try to reclaim the pivotal western Iraqi city from the Islamic State, American and Iraqi officials say.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Greece Given Until Sunday to Settle Debt Crisis or Face Disaster
articles.snippet: European leaders gave the Athens government until Sunday to reach an agreement to save its battered economy from a meltdown.
articles.abstract: European leaders gave the Athens government until Sunday to reach an agreement to save its battered economy from a meltdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Frustrated European leaders gave Greece until Sunday to reach an agreement to save its collapsing economy from catastrophe after an emergency summit meeting here on Tuesday ended without the Athens government offering a substantive new proposal to resolve its debt crisis.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and James Kanter

articles.headline: Islamic Battalions, Stocked With Chechens, Aid Ukraine in War With Rebels
articles.snippet: Acknowledging Moscow as an enemy shared with Kiev, one leader from Chechnya said, “We never ran from our war with Russia, and we never will.”
articles.abstract: Acknowledging Moscow as an enemy shared with Kiev, one leader from Chechnya said, “We never ran from our war with Russia, and we never will.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MARIUPOL, Ukraine — Wearing camouflage, with a bushy salt-and-pepper beard flowing over his chest and a bowie knife sheathed prominently in his belt, the man cut a fearsome figure in the nearly empty restaurant. Waiters hovered apprehensively near the kitchen, and try as he might, the man who calls himself “Muslim,” a former Chechen warlord, could not wave them over for more tea.

articles.headline: Security Experts Oppose Government Access to Encrypted Communication
articles.snippet: A new report says giving the governments “exceptional access” to encrypted communications would jeopardize confidential data and critical infrastructure.
articles.abstract: A new report says giving the governments “exceptional access” to encrypted communications would jeopardize confidential data and critical infrastructure.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — An elite group of security technologists has concluded that the American and British governments cannot demand special access to encrypted communications without putting the world’s most confidential data and critical infrastructure in danger.

articles.headline: The Prosecutor Who Says Louisiana Should ‘Kill More People’
articles.snippet: Dale Cox, the acting district attorney in Caddo Parish, La., has secured more than a third of Louisiana’s death sentences over the past five years.
articles.abstract: Dale Cox, the acting district attorney in Caddo Parish, La., has secured more than a third of Louisiana’s death sentences over the past five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHREVEPORT, La. — In a much-discussed dissent from the Supreme Court’s ruling on lethal injection last week, Justice Stephen G. Breyer laid out the problems, as he saw them, with the death penalty. Among them was “arbitrariness in application,” including how simple geography can determine whether someone convicted of murder would be sentenced to death.
